attachments.title: Git Large File Storage
attachments.text: Git Large File Storage (LFS) replaces large files such as audio samples, videos, datasets, and graphics with text pointers inside Git, while storing the file contents on a remote server like <http://GitHub.com|GitHub.com> or GitHub Enterprise.

attachments.title: A Dramatic Tour through Python’s Data Visualization Landscape (including ggplot and Altair)
attachments.text:
Why Even Try, Man?
I recently came upon Brian Granger and Jake VanderPlas’s Altair, a promising young visualization library. Altair seems well-suited to addressing Python’s ggplot envy, and its tie-in with JavaScript’s Vega-Lite grammar means that as the latter develops new functionality (e.g., tooltips and zooming), Altair benefits — seemingly for free!
Indeed, I was so impressed by Altair that the original thesis of my post was going to be: “Yo, use Altair.”
But then I began ruminating on my own Pythonic visualization habits, and — in a painful moment of self-reflection — realized I’m all over the place: I use a hodgepodge of tools and disjointed techniques depending on the task at hand (usually whichever library I first used to accomplish that task1).
This is no good. As the old saying goes: “The unexamined plot is not worth exporting to a PNG.” 
Thus, I’m using my discovery of Altair as an opportunity to step back — to investigate how Python’s statistical visualization options hang together. I hope this investigation proves helpful for you as well.
How’s This Gonna Go?
The conceit of this post will be: “You need to do Thing X. How would you do Thing X in matplotlib? pandas? Seaborn? ggplot? Altair?”  By doing many different Thing X’s, we’ll develop a reasonable list of pros, cons, and takeaways — or at least a whole bunch of code that might be somehow useful.
(Warning: this all may happen in the form of a two-act play.)
The Options (in ~Descending Order of Subjective Complexity)
First, let’s welcome our friends2:
matplotlib
The 800-pound gorilla — and like most 800-pound gorillas, this one should probably be avoided unless you genuinely need its power, e.g., to make a really custom plot or produce a publication-ready graphic.
pandas
“Come for the DataFrames; stay for the plotting convenience functions that are arguably more pleasant than the matplotlib code they supplant.” — rejected pandas taglines
(Bonus tidbit: the pandas team must include a few visualization nerds, as the library includes things like RadViz plots and Andrews Curves that I haven’t seen elsewhere.)
Seaborn
Seaborn has long been my go-to library for statistical visualization; it summarizes itself thusly:
“If matplotlib ‘tries to make easy things easy and hard things possible,’ seaborn tries to make a well-defined set of hard things easy too”
yhat’s ggplot
A Python implementation of the wonderfully declarative grammar of graphics. This isn’t a “feature-for-feature port of ggplot2,” but there’s strong feature overlap. (And speaking as a part-time R user, the main geoms seem to be in place.)
Altair
The new guy, Altair is a “declarative statistical visualization library” with an exceedingly pleasant API.
Wonderful. Now that our guests have arrived and checked their coats, let’s settle in for our very awkward dinner conversation. Our show is entitled…
Little Shop of Python Visualization Libraries (starring all libraries as themselves) 
ACT I: LINES AND DOTS
(In Scene 1, we’ll be dealing with a tidy data set named “ts.” It consists of three columns: a “dt” column (for dates); a “value” column (for values); and a “kind” column, which has four unique levels: A, B, C, and D. Here’s a preview…)

dt
kind
value
0
2000-01-01
A
1.442521
1
2000-01-02
A
1.981290
2
2000-01-03
A
1.586494
3
2000-01-04
A
1.378969
4
2000-01-05
A
-0.277937
Scene 1: How would you plot multiple time series on the same graph?
matplotlib: Ha! Haha! Beyond simple. While I could and would accomplish this task in any number of complex ways, I know your feeble brains would crumble under the weight of their ingenuity. Hence, I dumb it down, showing you two simple methods. In the first, I loop through your trumped-up matrix — I believe you peons call it a “Data” “Frame” — and subset it to the relevant time series. Next, I invoke my “plot” method and pass in the relevant columns from that subset.

# MATPLOTLIB
fig, ax = plt.subplots(1, 1,
                       figsize=(7.5, 5))

for k in ts.kind.unique():
    tmp = ts[ts.kind == k]
    ax.plot(tmp.dt, tmp.value, label=k)

ax.set(xlabel='Date',
       ylabel='Value',
       title='Random Timeseries')    

ax.legend(loc=2)
fig.autofmt_xdate()



MPL: Next, I enlist this chump (*motions to pandas*), and have him pivot this “Data” “Frame” so that it looks like this…

# in matplotlib-land, the notion of a tidy
# dataframe matters not
dfp = ts.pivot(index='dt', columns='kind', values='value')
dfp.head()

kind
A
B
C
D
dt




2000-01-01
1.442521
1.808741
0.437415
0.096980
2000-01-02
1.981290
2.277020
0.706127
-1.523108
2000-01-03
1.586494
3.474392
1.358063
-3.100735
2000-01-04
1.378969
2.906132
0.262223
-2.660599
2000-01-05
-0.277937
3.489553
0.796743
-3.417402

MPL:By transforming the data into an index with four columns — one for each line I want to plot — I can do the whole thing in one fell swoop (i.e., a single call of my “plot” function).

# MATPLOTLIB
fig, ax = plt.subplots(1, 1,
                       figsize=(7.5, 5))

ax.plot(dfp)

ax.set(xlabel='Date',
       ylabel='Value',
       title='Random Timeseries')

ax.legend(dfp.columns, loc=2)
fig.autofmt_xdate()



pandas (*looking timid*):  That was great, Mat. Really great. Thanks for including me. I do the same thing — hopefully as good? (*smiles weakly*)

# PANDAS
fig, ax = plt.subplots(1, 1,
                       figsize=(7.5, 5))

dfp.plot(ax=ax)

ax.set(xlabel='Date',
       ylabel='Value',
       title='Random Timeseries')

ax.legend(loc=2)
fig.autofmt_xdate()

 
pandas: It looks exactly the same, so I just won’t show it.
Seaborn (*smoking a cigarette and adjusting her beret*): Hmmm. Seems like an awful lot of data manipulation for a silly line graph. I mean, for loops and pivoting? This isn’t the 90’s or Microsoft Excel. I have this thing called a FacetGrid I picked up when I went abroad. You’ve probably never heard of it…

# SEABORN
g = sns.FacetGrid(ts, hue='kind', size=5, aspect=1.5)
g.map(plt.plot, 'dt', 'value').add_legend()
g.ax.set(xlabel='Date',
         ylabel='Value',
         title='Random Timeseries')
g.fig.autofmt_xdate()


 
SB: See? You hand FacetGrid your un-manipulated tidy data. At that point, passing in “kind” to the “hue” parameter means you’ll plot four different lines — one for each level in the “kind” field. The way you actually realize these four different lines is by mapping my FacetGrid to this Philistine’s (*motions to matplotlib*) plot function, and passing in “x” and “y” arguments. There are some things you need to keep in mind, obviously, like manually adding a legend, but nothing too challenging. Well, nothing too challenging for some of us…
ggplot: Wow, neat! I do something similar, but I do it like my big bro. Have you heard of him? He’s so coo–
SB: Who invited the kid?
GG: Check it out!

# GGPLOT
fig, ax = plt.subplots(1, 1, figsize=(7.5, 5))

g = ggplot(ts, aes(x='dt', y='value', color='kind')) + \
        geom_line(size=2.0) + \
        xlab('Date') + \
        ylab('Value') + \
        ggtitle('Random Timeseries')
g


 
GG (*picks up ggpot2 by Hadley Wickham and sounds out words*): Every plot is com — com — com-prised of data (e.g., “ts”), aesthetic mappings (e.g, “x”, “y”, “color”), and the geom…
attachments.fallback: Regress to Impress Link: A Dramatic Tour through Python’s Data Visualization Landscape (including ggplot and Altair)

messages.text:
Sick of seaborn (already?) perhaps Altair is for you: <https://dansaber.wordpress.com/2016/10/02/a-dramatic-tour-through-pythons-data-visualization-landscape-including-ggplot-and-altair/>
Haven’t tried it myself yet but it looks pretty good from here.

In week 4, we introduced MLE and I offered <http://times.cs.uiuc.edu/course/410/note/mle.pdf> as an optional reading. This tutorial compares MLE and what it calls LSE (but which we’re calling OLS–the full designation would be “ordinary least squares estimation”, but OLS == LSE). Anyway, now that we are returning to OLS/LSE (OLSE?) with linear regression, it might be a good time to review that paper. This is called the linear model. Next week we will touch on the _generalized_ linear model (GLM) which uses MLE instead of OLS as it is more generalizable but this week our solutions use OLS.
Thank you <@U1Y098S5B>  … it worked for me.

I haven’t changed the settings, it should be open to everyone. You may need to reconnect if you change your IP. That may require restarting your kernel. (It _shouldn’t_ require that, but sometimes the kernel will cache things and not refresh appropriately.) If that doesn’t work, please send me your error.
<@U1Y098S5B> ,  some of us can’t connect to postgres server from home … could you check on that ?

messages.text: brief and informative and clears confusions : <http://gradquant.ucr.edu/wp-content/uploads/2013/11/Maximum-Likelihood-and-Method-of-Moments-Estimation.pdf>
:ok_hand:

This is the best video I’ve found so far regarding MOM (relevant to prob 3). One thing I didn’t get until I saw this is that to apply MOM for a parameter estimation, we have to already known something about the distribution we are applying the estimation to—that is, we should already know which distribution we’re using, and thus what the established mean or variance is for that distribution in terms of the distribution parameters (e.g., mean = np for a binomial, or mean = lambda for a poisson). In retrospect, this should have been simple to see, since we can estimate parameters for a distribution only if we first know what distribution we are considering (stated differently, we cannot estimate anything if we don’t know what we’re estimating). But it’s a lot of info and I got confused. 

I think the first ~3.5 min are really relevant; but in our case instead of working with specific data points we are working with points in mathematical notation X1,…,Xn (I think).

<https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZnLiJnHa6po>

messages.text:
Forgot to mention: another reason why we use the log likelihood (and not just the likelihood) is to avoid an underflow error. (This was in the lecture notebook but I forgot to mention it.) You’ll notice, when calculating the likelihood of various :scheme:’s, that the values are very low. Not so low as to put you in danger of an underflow error, but it is easy to see how, with more data, that could easily happen.
(N.B. This will come up again when you learn Naïve Bayes and you are calculating the probability of seeing individual words in a document.)
You do not need to use the `fit.py` module from last week for today’s lab. Just follow the pattern established in the lecture, only for the distribution in question.
For question 1 this could help: <https://github.com/zipfian/DSCI6002-student/wiki/%5BCheat-Sheet%5D-Discrete-Distributions> shotout to the wiki

If you’re interested in a Bayesian approach, you can read more about how that works (and how to put it into practice!) at <http://nbviewer.jupyter.org/github/CamDavidsonPilon/Probabilistic-Programming-and-Bayesian-Methods-for-Hackers/blob/master/Chapter1_Introduction/Chapter1.ipynb>

messages.text: Another clarification on the midterm: For the last problem of Statistics/Random Sampling, make histograms of sample & population for a continuous variable of your choice (ignore the words "Attack points")

<https://onlinecourses.science.psu.edu/stat414/node/89> has a pretty good explanation of Exponential, Gamma, and Chi-Square distributions (including examples!) What it’s describing is really the *standard gamma distribution* which, like the *standard normal distribution* has a location of zero and a scale of one. See <http://www.itl.nist.gov/div898/handbook/eda/section3/eda366b.htm> for how that generalizes.

<!channel> a typo in the midterm was pointed out to me. It says "Make at least one boxplot of continuous variables grouped by a categorical variable” It _should_ say "Make at least one boxplot of a continuous variable grouped by a categorical variable”. In other words, for your second boxplot, only one continuous variable need be plotted (against another variable which should be categorical.)
Thanks <@U1UT96TL6> and <@U21KWCE7L> for the references!!

attachments.title: Probabilistic Systems Analysis and Applied Probability
attachments.text: Welcome to 6.041/6.431, a subject on the modeling and analysis of random phenomena and processes, including the basics of statistical inference. Nowadays, there is broad consensus that the ability to think probabilistically is a fundamental component of scientific literacy. For example: The concept of statistical significance (to be touched upon at the end of this course) is considered by the Financial Times as one of &quot;The Ten Things Everyone Should Know About Science&quot;. A recent Scientific American article argues that statistical literacy is crucial in making health-related decisions. Finally, an article in the New York Times identifies statistical data analysis as an upcoming profession, valuable everywhere, from Google and Netflix to the Office of Management and Budget. The aim of this class is to introduce the relevant models, skills, and tools, by combining mathematics with conceptual understanding and intuition.

<!channel>: Today’s lab (3.2) is due Thursday (the 15th) at 1pm.
(Part 1 of the Midterm is due Monday (the 19th) at 1pm)

Also, a clarification on kurtosis: as mentioned in class, the kurtosis of a normal distribution is 3. However, sometimes you’ll see “excess kurtosis” which is simply kurtosis - 3. So the “excess kurtosis” of a normal distribution is zero.
Simpson’s Paradox explained: <http://vudlab.com/simpsons/>
I am happy to answer clarification questions, if something seems vague or ambiguous, but I cannot _help_ you with the midterm. It is an assessment.

For the midterm: if you get multiple answers for your SQL query of "which Pokemon seems the most useful", you can return one or  multiple answers (feel free to justify why you believe one is the most useful)

For question 8, it looks like I was a little bit ambiguous. I intended for you to do a simulation based on your solution to question 7 and see how often you get a success. Another (more challenging) interpretation would be to simulate an unbounded number of purchases and see how long it takes to get 3 empirically. That's a different problem, also worthy of your time, but not what I intended.

(Pet peeve: the multi-armed bandit is a generalization of the "one-armed bandit” which was slang for a slot machine long before computer science. So each slot machine is a "one-armed bandit." The problem with multiple slot machines is therefore called the "multi-armed bandit”.)

attachments.title: The Three Faces of Bayes
attachments.text:
Last summer, I was at a conference having lunch with Hal Daume III&nbsp;when&nbsp;we got to talking about how &ldquo;Bayesian&rdquo; can be&nbsp;a funny and ambiguous term. It&nbsp;seems&nbsp;like&nbsp;the definition should be straightforward: &ldquo;following the work of English mathematician Rev. Thomas Bayes,&rdquo; perhaps, or even &ldquo;uses Bayes&rsquo; theorem.&rdquo; But many methods bearing the reverend&rsquo;s name or using his theorem aren&rsquo;t even considered &ldquo;Bayesian&rdquo; by his most religious followers. Why is it that Bayesian networks, for example, aren&rsquo;t considered&hellip; y&rsquo;know&hellip; Bayesian?
As I&rsquo;ve read more outside the fields of machine learning and natural language processing &mdash;&nbsp;from psychometrics and environmental biology to&nbsp;hackers who dabble in data science&nbsp;&mdash;&nbsp;I&rsquo;ve noticed three broad&nbsp;uses of the term &ldquo;Bayesian.&rdquo; I mentioned to Hal that I wanted to blog about these different uses, and he said it probably would have been more&nbsp;useful about six&nbsp;years ago when being &ldquo;Bayesian&rdquo; was&nbsp;all the&nbsp;rage&nbsp;(being &ldquo;deep&rdquo; is where it&rsquo;s at these days). I still think these are useful distinctions, though, so here it is anyway.
I&rsquo;ll present&nbsp;the three main uses&nbsp;of &ldquo;Bayesian&rdquo; as I understand them, all through the lens of&nbsp;a na&iuml;ve Bayes classifier. I hope you find it useful and interesting!
A Theorem By Any Other Name&hellip;
First off,&nbsp;Bayes&rsquo; theorem (in some form) is involved in all three takes on &ldquo;Bayesian.&rdquo; This 250-year-old staple of statistics gives us a way to estimate the probability of some outcome of interest  given some evidence :

If we care about inferring&nbsp; from&nbsp;, Bayes&rsquo; theorem says this can be done by estimating the joint probability  and then dividing by the marginal probability  to get the conditional probability . The second equivalence follows from the chain rule: .&nbsp; is called the prior distribution over , and&nbsp; is called the posterior&nbsp;distribution over  after having observed .
1. Bayesians Against Discrimination
Now&nbsp;briefly&nbsp;consider this photo from the Pittsburgh G20 protests in 2009. That&rsquo;s me carrying a sign that says &ldquo;Bayesians Against Discrimination&rdquo; behind the one and only John Oliver.&nbsp;I don&rsquo;t think he realized he was in satirical company at the time&nbsp;(photo by Arthur Gretton,&nbsp;more ML protest photos here).

To get the joke, you need to grasp the first interpretation of &ldquo;Bayesian&rdquo;: a model&nbsp;that uses Bayes&rsquo; theorem to make predictions given some data&hellip;

Bayesian networks are probabilistic models that rely on Bayes&rsquo;&nbsp;theorem, and a special case is the na&iuml;ve Bayes classifier. It&rsquo;s a popular model for&nbsp;text applications like spam filtering. Given a&nbsp;document &nbsp;as &ldquo;evidence,&rdquo; we want to predict the best label &nbsp;with&nbsp;the highest probability&nbsp; of  given . We can do that&nbsp;using&nbsp;the&nbsp;theorem like so:

If all&nbsp;we really care about is the best (most probable)&nbsp;, we can ignore the marginal  from&nbsp;the denominator of Bayes&rsquo; theorem, since it is fixed and constant for all labels&nbsp;(hence the proportional  in&nbsp;the second and third lines). The na&iuml;vit&eacute; of na&iuml;ve Bayes comes from the (not&nbsp;always&nbsp;realistic) assumption that the probability of each word  is independent of the others, given . This makes our lives easier by letting us just multiply all the class-conditional word probabilities together in order to estimate the joint probability: . Given a training&nbsp;set of labeled texts (e.g., spam vs.&nbsp;legit email), we can count up all the labels and words to estimate  and  probabilities into a set of classifier parameters we&rsquo;ll call . Taken together, the parameters in  approximate the joint probability . Then we use Bayes&rsquo; theorem to predict class labels for any new document . Nice!
A Bayesian network like na&iuml;ve Bayes is considered a generative model with a generative story. The generative story for na&iuml;ve Bayes goes like this:
to make a&nbsp;document, first sample a class label according to 
then, sample each word  in the document according to 
This story says we can generate new hypothetical documents because we approximated the full joint distribution . However, for classification we really just care about the conditional distribution , so we need&nbsp;to use Bayes&rsquo; theorem. In contrast, discriminative models like logistic regression assume that we don&rsquo;t care about the joint distribution&nbsp;to begin with, so why not just&nbsp;estimate  directly? Bayes&rsquo; theorem need not apply.
So&nbsp;the G20 protest joke interprets &ldquo;Bayesian&rdquo; to mean generative (not discriminative) modeling. In other words, if we&rsquo;re Bayesian, we want to model the joint probability of variables and use Bayes&rsquo; theorem to make predictions.
(Note: na&iuml;ve Bayes and logistic regression are considered a &ldquo;generative-discriminative pair,&rdquo; since they take the same graphical form, but parameters are estimated differently and have different interpretations; see Ng &amp; Jordan (2002)&nbsp;for more on this.)
2. If You Liked It, Then You Should&rsquo;ve&nbsp;Put A Prior On It
Now consider this high-profile reaction to our G20 joke:
I confess I don&rsquo;t understand the &ldquo;Bayesians against discrimination!&rdquo; sign. As Ng and Jordan have shown, Bayesians can make good use of both discriminative and generative methods.
~ Peter Norvig (Director of Research at Google)
Sensible as it may seem, the &ldquo;Bayesian == generative&rdquo; interpretation is pretty rare, and will probably get you laughed out of the room at a quant-nerd cocktail party (although let&rsquo;s be honest: these aren&rsquo;t the best cocktail parties). To understand Norvig&rsquo;s comment, you need to grasp&nbsp;our second interpretation of &ldquo;Bayesian&rdquo;: don&rsquo;t use Bayes&rsquo; theorem for prediction, use it for learning!
Given a training&nbsp;set  as &ldquo;evidence,&rdquo; the goal of machine learning is to pick&nbsp;the best model  with the highest probability . Well, we can do that&nbsp;using Bayes&rsquo; theorem, too:

Again, if we just care about the &ldquo;best&rdquo; model parameters  we can ignore  from&nbsp;the denominator of Bayes&rsquo; theorem, since the data are&nbsp;fixed and it&nbsp;would be constant anyway. So in this &ldquo;Bayesian&rdquo; way of learning,  is a function of  &mdash; the likelihood of the data given the model &mdash; and  &mdash; the &ldquo;prior&rdquo; distribution over all possible models. If we think all models are equally likely, we can ignore&nbsp;the prior and just maximize . This is called maximum likelihood estimation (MLE), and that&rsquo;s essentially how I described na&iuml;ve Bayes parameter learning&nbsp;in the previous section. Including a prior gives us maximum a posteriori (MAP) estimation: start with a prior distribution  and update it to a posterior distribution  after seeing some data.
(Note: using Bayes&rsquo; theorem for prediction, as we did in the first section, can be considered &ldquo;MAP inference…

If you’ve downloaded the titanic database to the same folder as your notebook, you can connect to it using `ipython-sql` using the following magic (after you’ve loaded the extension)
```
%sql sqlite:///titanic.db
```

Hi all, I’ve started a Anki deck for Pandas, which I plan to continue to update:
<https://ankiweb.net/shared/info/203373679>

Mou and MacDown are very similar. I don’t remember why I ended up settling on MacDown. It could be that there was something in particular that didn’t render well in Mou but did in MacDown. But there’s plenty of things that don’t render correctly in MacDown so….
If you would like to (or) need to see the rendering of the markdown, I’ve found Mou to be a really simple and effective tool.  <http://25.io/mou/>

attachments.title: 25.io | Mou - Markdown editor for developers, on Mac OS X.
attachments.text: Mou, Markdown editor for developers, on Mac OS X.
attachments.fallback: 25.io | Mou - Markdown editor for developers, on Mac OS X.

messages.text: A student asked about a markdown editor for Mac. The one I’ve been using is MacDown. It’s not great, but it’s the best I’ve found so far. If you find one you like better, please share. Otherwise, Atom works fine. It does have the ability to represent markdown in a side pane (I think that might require a plugin). In some ways it is better, in some ways worse than MacDown. I often end up using both.
